When looking through an old scrapbook one day recently A. T. Turner, manager of the Monarch Lumber Company, ran across the following article which should be of interest to many readers of this newspaper. It was taken from the North West Territories Gazette, Regina, published on Monday, June 19, 1905, just before the Province of Saskatchewan was formed.

Notice is hereby given in accordance with the provisions of the School ordinance in that behalf that by order of the Commissioner of Education the following lands, namely: Sections 8, 9, 10, 11; 14, 15, 16, 17; 20, 21, 22, 23; 26, 27, 28, 29; 32, 33, 34 and 35 in Township 31, Range 25, west of the second meridian, have been erected into a school district under the name of the Manual School District No. 1334 of the North West Territories.

(Signed) J. A. Calder,
Deputy Commissioner of Education.

The first three trustees elected were: T. N. Bjorndahl, for a term of three years; A. Wilde, 2 years, and R. Thomas, 1 year. T. N. Bjorndahl was appointed secretary-treasurer and A. Wilde, chairman, at the first meeting of the Board. The Board agreed that we pay $12 per M feet for hauling lumber to erect a schoolhouse, from either Davidson or Humboldt. The schoolhouse to be 14 x 24 xg, with four windows and one door. $500 in debentures were issued for the cost of the school. The contract for building the school was awarded to A. M. Skevik who submitted the lowest bid, $43.00.

In July, 1905, L. A. Pearson was engaged to teach in the school at $45 per month.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A work of examination to the period answered by this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to you, so don't worry about answering them. If there is not sufficient space to answer the question, don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in their province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Western Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you are willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

24. Did you ever visit the place where your parents lived?
Most of the people thought it was cold enough there without going farther north. Some of our friends asked us, "Why go up to the Klondike to freeze?" They razzed us about the cold in every letter until midwinter. Then we found a butterfly outside amongst our packing crates during a mild spell in February. We wrote and asked them if they could match that! We never heard another word about the Klondike.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? Most all of the buildings were made of sod. The walls 2½ feet thick. The homes had board ceilings & floors, window sashes & doors. Inside walls were plastered & whitewashed. Warm & cozy inside but not much to look at outside - just black soil. At first there were very few families to compare with the number of bachelors. Needless to say Mrs. Bjornsdahl's mother, Mrs. Anna Johnson, were especially overjoyed with the arrival of every new bride into the district. It not only broadened social life but increased the demand for bread making which often amounted to 20 loaves a day for three two-roomers - no bake shops then.

EARLY HISTORY OF THE TOWN OF WATROUS

On the 11th day of November, 1903, three young men, B.B. Haaland, T.N. Bjorndahl and T. Odne, journeyed out from Davidson, Saskatchewan, by democrat, to Manitou Lake, looking for homesteads. They found good land just south of the lake and decided to settle there. However the land was not open for filing on, so they returned to their homes in Edmore, North Dakota.

The next summer the land was opened for settlement and these men returned July 4th, 1904, built sod shacks into which their families moved in the fall. In the summer of 1904 much land settlement took place and homesteaders shacks dotted the countryside for miles round. A post office was the first necessity, the nearest one being 51 miles south-east (Davidson). Application was made to open a post-office by the name of "Mandal", and T. N. Bjorndahl was the first postmaster. The mail route was up from Regina, Lumsden, Strasbourg, Taylorborre, Peacock, Ridgeford, to Mandal. It is hardly possible for us to realize the difficulty and danger involved in hauling mail by horse team and democrat or lumber wagon through winter snows and spring thaws -- but the mail came through regularly, twice a week, via this route and means until the steel came through.

The village of Madal popped up like a mushroom. Mr. Bjorndahl opened a general store and blacksmith shop. The next spring Dr. J. H. White opened a drug store; J. J. Abraham and J. Elsworth opened a real estate office; OmN. Bjorndahl started a restaurant and butcher shop; the North American Lumber Company put in a lumber yard. A school board was soon elected with N. Thomas, R. Wildie, and T. N. Bjorndahl as trustees. The first term was held in a sod shack on the homestead.

T. N. Bjorndahl, secretary-treasurer, made up the first school board. A. J. Gordon and Miss Dainard were teachers; attendance was approximately 60.

EARLY HISTORY OF THE TOWN OF MATROUS

On the 11th day of November, 1903, three young men, B.B. Haaland, T. N. Bjornsdahl and T. Ohno, journeyed out from Davidson, Saskatchewan, by canoe, to Hanitou Lake, looking for homesteads. They found good land just south of the lake and decided to settle there. However the land was not open for filing on, so they returned to their homes in Minnesota, North Dakota.

The next summer the land was opened for settlement and these men returned July 4th, 1904, built sod shacks into which their families moved in the fall. In the summer of 1904, much land settlement took place and homesteaders shacks dotted the countryside for miles around.

A post office was the first necessity, the nearest one being 51 miles southeast (Davidson). Application was made to open a post-office by the name of Matrous, and T. N. Bjornsdahl was the first postmaster.

The mail route was up from Regina, Lumsden, Strasbourg, Taylorboro, Peacock, Ridgeway, to Matrous. It is hardly possible for us to realize the difficulty and danger involved in hauling mail by horse team and democrat or lumber wagon through winter snows and spring thaws — but the mail came through regularly, twice a week, via this route and means until the steel came through.

The village of Matrous popped up like a mushroom. Mr. Bjornsdahl opened a general store and blacksmith shop. The next spring Dr. J. H. White opened a drug store; J. J. Abraham and J. Elsworth opened a real estate office; O.M. Bjornsdahl started a restaurant and butcher shop; the North American Lumber Company put in a lumber yard. A school board was soon elected with Mr. Thomas, R. Wildie, and T. N. Bjornsdahl as trustees. The first term was held in a sod shack on the homestead.

In the fall of 1906 engineers came through, surveying for the Grand Trunk Pacific Railroad, what is now the main line of the C.N.R. transcontinental. In 1907 the grade was completed and the townsite of Watrous was surveyed one mile east of the village of Mandal (on the Homestead). This location was decided more adaptable for a railroad stop, hence the village of Mandal was "moved" and the name changed to "Watrous" by the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway Company — thus naming the town after one of their directors and keeping this divisional point in alphabetical order in the line.

The first man to build on the new townsite was Frank Keebler who put up a small shack for a harness shop on the east side of Main Street in the late fall of 1907. In the spring of 1908 the townsite of Watrous was put on the market and the town grew rapidly. The first church service was held in Hultgreen and Thurston's lumber yard, and conducted by the missionary minister, R. Surtice, who was shortly after replaced by Reverend Vessey of the Methodist Church. The first church erected was the Anglican; Reverend H. King took charge. The (Reverend John Mason, pastor), Norwegian Lutheran, and Presbyterian churches soon followed. School was opened in the Hiltz Building on 2nd Avenue and Main Street on December 1st., 1908. O.M. Holm, Harry Schlater, with T. N. Bjorndahl, secretary-treasurer, made up the first school board. A. J. Gordon and Miss Dainard were teachers; attendance was approximately 60.

On July 1st, 1908, the first celebration was held, sponsored by the Watrous Citizens' Band under the direction of band leader W. H. McVaugh.

The first baby born in Watrous was a son to Mr. and Mrs. George Saunders, named Colonel; the baby was presented with a carriage from the town. The first baby girl born was to Mr. and Mrs. D. A. Mollard and called Jean.
